Company: CSC Accounts Management Inc., d/b/a CSC Credit Services, Inc.
Description: A consumer debt collection company agreed to pay the United States more than $6.4 million to settle allegations that it made false claims in connection with defaulted student loans under the Federal Family Education Loan Program and the William D. Ford Direct Student Loan Program.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took action against Equifax, Inc., TransUnion, and their subsidiaries for deceiving consumers about the usefulness and actual cost of credit scores they sold to consumers. The companies were also accused of luring consumers into costly recurring payments for credit-related products with false promises.

Equifax Credit Information Services, Inc. agreed to pay $250,000 to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that its blocked-call rate and hold times violated provisions of an FTC consent decree that settled a 2000 lawsuit for violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act.

Three national consumer reporting agencies agreed to a total of $2.5 million in payments as part of settlements of allegations that they each violated provisions of the Fair Credit Reporting Act by failing to maintain a toll-free telephone number with personnel accessible to consumers during normal business hours.

Following a public comment period, the Federal Trade Commission approved a final order settling charges that Equifax Information Services LLC violated the Fair Credit Reporting Act and Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act by improperly selling lists of millions of consumers who were late on their mortgages.

TALX Corporation, a subsidiary of Equifax Inc., agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it violated federal law by failing to provide certain disclosures to users of their consumer reports and to entities that provide information for consumer reports.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Private Litigation Case Title: Soutter v. Equifax Information Services, LLC

Description: As part of the settlement of allegations that it engaged in unfair and deceptive practices in connection with a 2017 data breach, Equifax agreed to provide $425 million in consumer relief and pay a $100 million civil penalty to the CFPB. It also paid $175 million to the states (see separate entry).

Equifax agreed to pay $175 million to 47 states as part of the settlement of claims stemming from a 2017 data breach that exposed the personal information of more than 147 million consumers. At the same time, Equifax agreed to create a consumer redress fund of at least $300 million and pay a $100 million civil penalty to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

Experian, TransUnion, and Equifax agreed to pay a total of $7.175 million to settle allegations they engaged in deceptive marketing activities by signing up customers to credit monitoring services they were unaware of, and also produced credit reports that failed to properly verify information and did not take into account Mississippi law. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among the three.

Equifax Information Services, Experian Information Solutions and TransUnion agreed to pay a total of $6 million to settle multistate allegations relating to their handling of consumer disputes about credit report errors, monitoring and disciplining data furnishers (providers of credit reporting information), accuracy in consumer credit reports, and the marketing of credit monitoring products to consumers who call the credit reporting agencies to dispute information on their credit report. The settlement did not specify how the $6 million cost would be split among the three companies; we assume each paid $2 million.

Private Litigation Case Title: IN RE: EQUIFAX, INC., Customer Data Security Breach Litigation
